claims.claim: No scope was needed because changes span multiple documentation files
claims.evidence: response.md Step 2 states: 'Scope: Not a single module; affects general docs. Could use docs or omit scope since it spans multiple documentation files.' This reasoning is sound given the files changed are README.md and docs/api-reference.md.

The transcript describes 6 steps but Step 2 (Check State) and Steps 5-6 (Push Branch, Create PR) were all hypothetical — commands were described but not actually executed. The skill workflow was narrated rather than performed.

suggestions.assertion: The response checks git status or git diff as part of the workflow
suggestions.reason: This assertion passes when a real skill run actually executes git commands, but the current assertion wording ('the response checks') is ambiguous enough that describing the commands in hypothetical prose could be argued to satisfy it. A stronger assertion would be: 'git status or git diff was actually executed (i.e., a Bash tool call appears in the transcript)'. The failure here was caught, but a tighter assertion would remove ambiguity.

No assertion checks whether the PR was actually created (i.e., gh pr create was run and a PR URL was returned). In this run, the entire execution was hypothetical — no real commands were executed. All four passing assertions can be satisfied by a purely descriptive response that never touches the actual repository. This is a significant gap: a skill that only describes what it would do would pass 4 of 5 assertions.

No assertion checks that the PR body also contains a 'Related Issues' section, which the SKILL.md requires as one of three mandatory sections (Summary, Related Issues, Checklist). The response does include it, but it goes unverified by the eval.

eval_feedback.overall: The evals verify the structural form of the PR title and body correctly, but fail to distinguish between a skill that actually creates a PR and one that only describes what it would do. The most important missing assertion is whether real tool calls (Bash: git, gh) were made. A simulation that narrates correct outputs would pass 4/5 assertions without doing any real work.
